prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
As explained in the Sensitivity justification, we require a spectral resolution < 0.2 km/s to accurately capture the dynamics of the molecular gas. The ionised gas will have much higher line widths (~ 20km/s), however the dynamical properties need to be quantified to a similar level of precision. We have spectrally averaged by a factor of four (to ~0.25 km/s) to reduce the data rate, but maintain a velocity resolution consistent with characterising 1 km/s line shifts, which are likely despite the expected FWHM of 20 km/s (see, for instance Klaassen et al. 2013).
We have relaxed the high velocity resolution constraint for the windows capturing the CH3CN emission. This was required to capture the largest number of K components, and accurately determine the temperature of the hot cores surrounding the HII Regions. The second (1/2) spectral window is neccessary to capture the K=9,10,11 lines. K=9 is important because it (along with K=3,6) have different optical depths (abundances) than the other transitions and can constrain the optical depth of the gas, and the K=11 transition traces gas upwards of 1000 K - that closest to the HII region itself. These bands have also been spectrally averaged by a factor of 2 to reduce data rates.

Angular Resolution: 0.45" corresponds to 1/3 of the size of the smallest HII region in our sample (1.3"). One of our goals is to spatially and spectrally resolve the ionised gas dynamics, which sets this limit.
Largest Angular Scale: The 5 GHz continuum emission in Figure 2 suggests that these HII regions can reach sizes comparable to the Band 7 primary beam. However, the compact core of the emission (where we expect to detect radio recombination lines) is *in all cases* less than 6" across. The molecular emission (in CH3CN and SO2) is expected to be slightly (a few arcsec) larger than this (See, for instance Klaassen et al. 2009). This sets our largest angular scale requirement at 8.5"

The bandwidth used for our sensitivity calculation is based on our requested spectral resolution. This is required to properly quantify the molecular gas motions with FWHM line widths of 2-3 km/s. To examine kinematic signatures (e.g. infall, rotation, outflow) we need to resolve structure within the lines, not just their peaks. For spectro-astrometry, we need much better than Nyquist sampling of the main line to resolve spatial line gradients.
Our sensitivity calculations are based primarily on clear detection of the Hydrogen recombination line at 284 GHz. This required calculating the (free-free) continuum flux, and from that, using standard RRL line to continuum flux ratios to determine the line flux.
Assuming an emission measure of EM = 1e8 (typical of hypercompact HII regions, see Sewilo et al. 2004), and and electron temperature of T = 1e4 K, we determined that our HII regions become optically thin at ~ 5GHz (see equation 10.37 of Tools of Radio Astronomy, v5). From this frequency (for which we show the archive VLA emission in Figure 2 for all sources), optically thin free-free emission scales with frequency to the power of -0.1. Using that spectral index, we determined the free-free continuum emission contribution at 284 GHz.
We then scaled to the expected line peak brightness using equation 10 of Brown et al. (1978), and a FWHM line width of 20 km/s (as seen in H29a in our Cycle 2 data).
Our sensitivity limit was then chosen to ensure detection of even the faintest Hydrogen recombination line: The H28a from G12.43 is expected to peak at 124 mJy/beam, constituting a S/N of 9. With this, we will be able to measure substructures in the lines (rotation, infall, etc) down to a factor of 2 from the peak brightness.
We note that the free-free emission at 284 GHz will be much lower than the thermal dust contribution. Thus, our continuum flux estimates are strict lower limits. Wihtout full high-resolution SED modelling of each individual region, we cannot place consistent limits on the thermal dust component across the sample.

As explained in the sensitivity justification, we require a spectral resolution < 0.2 km/s to accurately capture the dynamics of the molecular gas. The ionised gas will have much higher line widths (> 20 km/s), however the dynamical properties need to be quantified on to a similar level of precision. We have therefore spectrally averaged the RRL spectral window by a factor of 4 (to 0.288 km/s) to minimise the data rate, but maintain a high enough spectral resolution to quantify gas kinematics at the 1 km/s level

Angular Resolution: 0.6" corresponds to roughly 1/2 of the size of the smallest HII region (1.3") in our sample. We can use the Band 7 observations to quantify the dynamics, while the band 3 observations will be used to quantify the HII region itself, which does not require as much spatial resolution. At 0.6", we only require 2 main array configurations to capture the large scale emission at high enough spatial resolution to marginally resolve the HII regions.
Largest Angular Scale: We have CO (SMA + JCMT) maps of G28.2 and G10.6 (see Klaassen et al. 2011). In these cases, the CO reaches extents of ~ 20". Higher density tracers such as HCO+ are likely to be less extended than CO. The structures we aim to resolve are primarily at high velocities and fairly compact and should be unaffected by un-imaged features in the sidelobes.

The bandwidth used for our sensitivity calculation is based on our requested spectral resolution. This is required to properly quantify the molecular gas motions with FWHM line widths of 2-3 km/s (To sensitively determine shifts in a 2 km/s line requires sub 0.2 km/s spectral resolution).
Our sensitivity calculations are based primarily on clear detection of the Hydrogen recombination line at 99 GHz. This required calculating the (free-free) continuum flux, and from that using standard RRL line to continuum ratios to determine the line flux.
Assuming an emission measure of EM = 1e8 (typical of hypercompact HII regions, see Sewilo et al. 2004), and an electron temperature of T = 1e4 K, we determiend that our HII regions become optically thin at ~ 5 GHz (see equation 10.37 of Tools of Radio Astronomy, v5). From this frequency (for which we show the archive VLA emissino in Figure 2 for all sourceS), optically thin free-free emission scales with frequency to the power of -0.1. Using that spectral index, we determined the continuum emission at 99 GHz.
We then scaled to the expected peak brightness using equation 10 of Brown et al. (1978), and FWHM line width of 20 km/s (as seen in H29a in our Cycle 2 data).
Our sensitivity limit was then chosen to ensure detection of even the faintest Hydrogen Recombination line (The H40a from G12.43 is expected to peak at 44 mJy/beam, constituting a S/N of ~8). With this, we will be able to measure substructures in the lines (rotation, infall, etc) down to a factor of 2 from the peak brightness.
We note that the free-free emission at 99 GHz will be lower than the thermal dust contribution. Thus, our continuum flux estimates are strict lower limits. Wihtout full high-resolution SED modelling of each individual region, we cannot place consistent limits on the thermal dust component across the sample.

Note on Configurations: because of the more northern declinations of these sources, we require two main array configurations to properly image on the relevant size scales (including resolution and largest scale). These are some of the most distant sources in our sample, and so keeping the high resolution is crucial to our science goals

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Stars with masses greater than 100 M_sun are known to exist in our Galaxy. How they obtain that mass is, as yet, an unresolved problem. Above ~30 M_sun, accretion scenarios known to be involved in the formation of lower mass stars may cease to be applicable as HII regions begin to form. Here we propose to observe the ionised and molecular gas dynamics in a sample of regions forming O stars (>30 M_sun) to quantify these unconstrained accretion processes. Is the accretion self-shielded and molecular, or ionised? These two scenarios are expected to have measurably different kinematics, which we will exploit to determine the primary means by which the most massive stars in our Galaxy gain their mass. These observations will shape our understanding of accretion at the top end of the initial mass function, whether there is an upper limit to it, and what sets that limit.
We propose band 3 and 7 observations of a number of molecular (HCO+, SiO, CH3CN, SO2) and ionised (Hydrogen and Helium radio recombination lines 28a and 40a) gas tracers to determine the gas dynamics and internal properties of the brightest (L > 10^5 L_sun) HII regions in our Galaxy (within a distance limit of 6 kpc).

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Physics and Astronomy, Leeds, The University of
